pulls.title: CORE beacon scalability
pulls.author: tzaeschke
pulls.body:
Discussion on core beacon scalability and Recovery

Contributes to #2

comments.body: Is it superexponential with the number of ASes? I thought it was _just_ exponential.

I don't think it would limit the number of available paths, after enough time of beaconing.
Those 5 beacons may be part of a different path than the previous ones. Same for the next ones, and so on.
I think usually the same 5 paths would forwarded every time, if they are the best paths, then should it change and forward other paths? Or not?

Two things: 
- I'd clarify the context for this number.. Is it in total in an overall SCION network? Is it per AS? I think it makes sense to talk about numbers per AS in general
- According to our (@matzf ) calculations and my understanding, if you limit the number of beacons with the "best PCB" practice, then the number is o(N*log(N)). So this would be if you were to not filter the number of beacons at all?
- I'd explain more clearly what "naively" means, e.g. `if there were no limits to the numbers of beacons propagated by each core AS, the number of paths and beacons would grow exponentially`)

```suggestion
* It limits the number of available paths for endpoints such that only 5 path may be available to a given destination. This is especially relevant for
```

In drafts, we use `endpoint`  as per definition in RFC9473. Could you generally use endpoint instead of end host?

> such that only 5 path may be available to a given destination.  

This text gives the impression that there are at most 5 paths between a src and dst, which is not the case. Is this just an edge case? I think in general more paths are available between endpoints

```
  * Unusual path policies, such as geofencing, may not be fulfillable by the limited number of paths on offer.
```
Was this ever an actual problem? Is it an edge case? I've never heard of this before

Are you referring to the `Wormhole Attack` we describe in the CP draft? 
Why is this related to core beaconing scalability?
Wouldn't a wormhole segment work? Is this section about segment revocation?

Not sure it happened yet, simply because we do not have much useful metadata yet (geofencing etc).
I think it can become a problem: if all ASes only forward their best five paths, then these five paths may be disjunct in themselves, but neighboring ASes are probably likely to forward the (almost) same 5 paths. In effect, an endpoint may have more than 5 paths available, but they are likely to be very similar and may not offer the choice that an endpoint desires?
I added an explanation. Does it make sense? Otherwise I can remove the whole bullet point.

For this to happen, these neighbors have to share a common trailing path, e.g., being X our AS:
```
1) a->b->c -> X
2) a'->b'->c' -> X
etc.
```
Paths 1 and 2 would be "similar" if a' ≈ a and b'≈ b, while having c and c' being different neighbors.
Definitely not an impossible situation, but also not common: most likely the trailing path of neighbor c will be different that that of neighbor c', either in AS numbers or interface IDs.

I don't agree with this. It might limit the number of paths if and only if there are no _new_ beacons arriving to the neighboring ASes after **N** beaconing periods. For that to happen, we require that the beaconing step _i+1_ forwards the same beacons than step _i_. OR that the beacons are very short lived and cannot survive longer than one period.
In any other case, period _i+1_ could, and would, forward different beacons to the neighboring ASes.

This is how I would explain it.
- The time needed to propagate all the beacons to the neighboring ASes increments.
- Since all beacons have an expiration time, we have a finite amount of time until a beaconing period will need to forward an already forwarded beacon, just because it expired.
- And, _most importantly_, the semantics of what a "best PCB" means, are defined locally by the **beacon forwarder AS**, not by the receiver AS, who is the actual judge of the quality of the PCB.

I agree with @tzaeschke _iff_ they forward the same PCBs during each beaconing period.
Let me give an example to clarify:
- First AS "A" discriminates good PCBs using latency criteria. This means that for AS "A" only good latency PCBs are forwarded.
- Second AS "B" receives PCBs from AS "A", but "B" discriminates bases on bandwidth. Maybe some PCBs have a good bandwidth, but many were already filtered by "A".
- etc.

If ASes forward _all received beacons_ (in general, and assuming there is no expiration time inside the PCBs), there should not be a problem, since all paths will be eventually discovered.

Now, because reality is that ASes cannot forward all of the PCBs, the non forwarded PCBs (those that an AS never forwards) are the least interesting ones _according to the local criteria of that AS_, which may or may not coincide with that criteria of the next neighbors this PCB will encounter.

I believe this to be clearer if explained in terms of completeness of the graph exploration vs. time needed for it.

See comments above: only if the exploration achieved by this beaconing is very far from a full exploration of the complete graph, when the equality operator here `link1 = link2` means they have the same four tuple `[AS1,interface number1, AS2, interface number2]`

The possibility of attacking the selection of the best paths does not appear due to this beaconing process.
The same issue appears with an e.g. push-pull-publish-subscribe method, as long as the information propagated in the PCBs is trusted by the AS selecting the beacons and paths. Be that information latency, bandwidth, number of hops, etc (anything).

Maybe refresh the process of an endpoint requesting a path from itself as SRC, to a given DST.
This will make clear how the core ASes' control service is contacted, how many times, etc.
This is not immediately clear to me: why _mostly_ redundant information?
Three round trips from the local control service to control services of other two ASes.
I don't understand the approach. Can you clarify?
Although we could revisit the topic, path revocation was studied already, and brought only more problems into the picture. For a full rationale, see the SCION book v2, 5.7 Path Revokation
As a comment: This is essentially what the book promises, that the endpoints will have anyway a big selection to choose paths from.

```suggestion
Critically, there is no current way to recover from this situation. In order to recover, ASes that are connected to the
```
Thanks for the pointer. It turns out, path revocation comes basically for free with 2-phase beaconing :-D.

Is there a concept of emitting information to invalidate a previously authorized PCB?
If so, that is what we call a revocation. If it is not possible to invalidate previously authorized PCB, then I would call it differently, to distinguish from _revocation_ used in the book or previous I-Ds.

Just to clarify the example, we are looking for paths from X to Y:
```
1) Y->a->b->c -> X
2) Y->a'->b'->c' -> X
```
At a first step I'd argue that it is quite likely that, going from Y->X,  we have a'=a. If a=a' then the same argument applies to b=b' and so forth.
Consequently I'd argue that there is a high probability of overlap.

Unfortunately, I don't think there is any analysis or experiments to confirm/reject this. If people think this is wrong then we can remove it. Or I can try to rephrase it as a research question that would need to be clarified whether this may be a problem or not?

Sorry, I don't understand what you are saying. Maybe you can clarify?

My assumption is that an AS will rarely change it's what-is-the-best-PCB algorithm. Consequently, they would always forward the same five segments. They may receive new beacons, but as long as the "best 5" are still among them (and I assume they will be, why shouldn'´t they?), they will continue forwarding these 5 PCBs.
I actually meant from the local endpoint to the local control server. I am less concerned about roundtrips between ASes, they have stonger machines and better connections.
I did. Can you have another look?
Done
Done.

Okay, I think you mean if you combining ASes into ISD an see how many distinct ISD you can get? Interesting thought.

The question posed in this section relates to how many ISDs and ASes we expect, and what upper bound we have for them. E.g. 16 bits for ISD numbers allow only for ~16K distinct ISDs.
Yes, it refers to an AS being part of multiple ISDs.
Not infinite if the criteria to establish an ISD (trust relationship, and "type" like country, etc) is finite.

For capacity, an example would be "Tier Level". An AS would belong to only one ISD, but there might be many e.g. "Tier-2" ISDs, since not all ASes that fall into the category tier-2 can directly connect with each other.

Hi Ali, thanks a lot for this initial text. I've added some specific comments above, then some more general comments: 
- I feel that overall the key question about beaconing is to improve the tradeoffs between scalability/finding sufficient paths and doing it quickly. I'd try to highlight that in the text
- This topics connects to question 2.7  of RFC9217 (and also a bit 2.8)
  > Competing control inputs from path-aware endpoints and the routing control plane may lead to more difficult traffic engineering or non-convergent forwarding, especially if the endpoints' and operators' notion of the "best" path for given traffic diverges significantly. 
  
  I'd mention that, and that this has implications for traffic engineering. This is a question that we get a lot at IETF. I'd almost call this paragraph `Beacon optimization and traffic engineering` if this could fit..
